title: Another Excuse to Disrupt Education
summary: Teachers union boss suddenly open to vaccine mandates.. How long will teachers unions continue to create obstacles to normal school operation while claiming to favor it? Witness the American Federation of Teachers. The union has launched a $5 million campaign promoting the idea that it favors school reopening-at the same time its president fans Covid fears in the media and proposes new rules on classroom safety.

title: NBC Draws Its Lowest Summer Olympics Ratings Ever
summary: TV viewership down 42% from 2016; NBC executive said Olympics will still 'will be very, very profitable'. Olympic athletes like Caeleb Dressel, Suni Lee and Sydney McLaughlin helped the U.S. win the most gold medals at the Tokyo Summer Games. For Comcast Corp.'s NBCUniversal, however, the size of the audience that watched was underwhelming.

title: Pentagon to Mandate Covid-19 Vaccine for U.S. Service Members
summary: President Biden backs plan to add coronavirus vaccine to U.S. military's list of required shots by mid-September. WASHINGTON-Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin on Monday said he would make Covid-19 vaccination mandatory for U.S service members by mid-September, an effort by the Biden administration to combat the highly contagious Delta variant sweeping across the country.

title: A Climate of Catastrophe
summary: The facts in the new U.N. report aren't as dire as its advertising.. The world awoke Monday after a logy August weekend to some alarming news: The climate Apocalypse is nigh, humanity is to blame, and unless the world remakes the global economy, havoc and death are inevitable. Repent of your sins all ye who enter here.

title: Biden's 'Gamesmanship' on Evictions
summary: The judge weighing the new national ban sees this for what it is.. Judge Dabney Friedrich seems unwilling to play dumb for President Biden's political benefit, which shouldn't shock anyone, except maybe White House denizens. The facts are simply too hard to escape. After the Biden Administration repeatedly argued it lacked the authority to renew a national eviction ban, it did so regardless.

title: Blinken's Warning on China's Nukes
summary: Its growing ICBM arsenal is finally on the Administration's radar.. America's diplomatic differences with China on trade, Taiwan, the South China Sea and much else are familiar. But a new issue may be moving to center stage: Beijing's historic buildup of intercontinental ballistic missiles.

title: Biden's Polarizing Title IX Czar
summary: The education culture warrior fails in committee on a tie vote.. President Biden has had an easy time getting even his most partisan nominees through the Democratic Senate. But an exception could be Catherine Lhamon to be assistant secretary for civil rights at the Education Department.

title: Let Alta Fixsler Go
summary: Jewish law and values come up against the U.K.'s National Health Service.. In the Book of Exodus, the Lord tells the children of Israel that he is a jealous God and warns them not to put others before him. Today the plight of a 2-year-old Jewish girl named Alta Fixsler suggests the U.K.'s National Health Service has come to regard its own authority with an almost Old Testament jealousy.

title: De Blasio Banishes My Kids From New York
summary: His vaccine decree relegates them to second-class status.. When my son, 13, went for his annual physical, the topic of Covid vaccination came up. My wife explained that we are holding off until we gain confidence in the risk-benefit analysis for healthy adolescents, especially with regard to postvaccine myocarditis. The doctor acknowledged the concern and explained why she strongly recommended our son get vaccinated anyway. My wife thanked her and said we would continue to monitor the available data.

title: Leon Black Accuser Amends Lawsuit, Alleging Epstein Ties
summary: Former Apollo CEO's lawyer says new claims are 'demonstrably and transparently false'. A woman who accused former Apollo Global Management Inc. Chief Executive Leon Black of rape and defamation filed an amended complaint that alleges the private-equity titan was "best friends" with the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and once flew her to Florida for a potential sexual encounter involving Epstein.

title: 'The Long Game' Review: Asia First, Then the World
summary: Beijing seeks to blunt American order in Asia, build dependence on China throughout the region and expand its dominance globally.. In 1998 a former People's Liberation Army basketball player turned businessman, Xu Zengping, purchased the Varyag, a never-completed Soviet aircraft-carrier hull rotting in a Ukrainian shipyard. Publicly, Mr. Xu played a free-spending tycoon hoping to repurpose the ship as a floating casino. He was in fact the front man for a Chinese military acquisition. The previous year, a Chinese Navy vice admiral had asked him to be the go-between in Beijing's attempt to obtain the Varyag. In the words of Mr. Xu, "he held my hand and said, 'please do me a favor-go and buy [the carrier] and bring it back for our country and our army.' "

title: A Pediatric Association Stifles Debate on Gender Dysphoria
summary: Doctors who question the orthodoxy won't be allowed to set up a booth at its annual conference.. Is it safe for adolescents to undergo gender "transition"? Is it wise for children to take hormones that block puberty? The American Academy of Pediatrics not only has answered these questions in the affirmative but is determined to stifle any debate. On Friday the AAP told an international consortium of more than 100 clinicians and researchers who doubt the reigning orthodoxy that they couldn't set up an information booth at the association's national conference. The cosmetics company L'Oreal and the National Peanut Board will be there, but not the Society for Evidence-Based Gender Medicine.

title: Canadian Pacific Plans New, Higher Bid for Kansas City Southern
summary: Move would reignite takeover battle with Canadian National Railway for the U.S. railroad. Canadian Pacific Railway Ltd. is planning to make a new, increased offer for Kansas City Southern , according to people familiar with the matter, reigniting a takeover battle with Canadian National Railway Co. for the coveted U.S. railroad.

title: Notable & Quotable: Norms
summary: 'I come from a tradition in which you sometimes have to violate bad laws-by any means necessary.'. Elie Mystelwriting for the Nation, Aug. 9:

title: U.S. Fines Radar Company for Unauthorized Exports to China, Russia
summary: Keysight Technologies agrees to pay $6.6 million penalty, hire compliance officer. WASHINGTON-The State Department on Monday fined a Silicon Valley technology testing company that acknowledged violating rules governing the export of sensitive U.S. defense technology.

title: Belarus's Lukashenko Defiant After West Reveals More Sanctions
summary: Longtime leader dismissed his political opponents as foreign-backed agents, a year after claiming victory in disputed election. MINSK, Belarus-Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko struck a defiant note at an hourslong televised briefing a year after claiming victory in a disputed election, scoffing at Western sanctions and vowing never to cede power to his political opponents, whom he dismissed as foreign-backed agents.

title: Dow, S&P 500 Decline as Oil Slides
summary: Drop in crude prices signals investor unease about the economic recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 retreated as a tumble in oil prices signaled investor unease about the Covid-19 pandemic and the strength of the economic recovery.

title: Crypto Exchange Poloniex to Pay $10 Million to Settle SEC Probe
summary: Regulator alleges the firm should have registered its trading platform. WASHINGTON-An unregulated cryptocurrency exchange whose employees said they wanted to be aggressive about trading digital assets, even though their legal status was uncertain, has agreed to pay $10 million to settle a regulatory investigation.

title: The Rise of the 'Project' and the Slow Death of the Band
summary: Tame Impala, Waxahatchee and Soccer Mommy are just some of the most successful monikers under which solo indie artists perform today.

title: Taliban Make New Gains in Afghanistan, Putting Kabul in Crisis
summary: Setback came after warlord switched sides, as President Ashraf Ghani faces renewed pressure to create common front or resign. KABUL-The Taliban captured the capital of the strategic Samangan province on Monday after a prominent pro-government commander switched sides, nearly completing their sweep of northern Afghanistan and intensifying a political crisis in Kabul.

title: Assembly to Hold Hearings in Cuomo Impeachment Probe
summary: Several women have accused Democratic governor of sexual harassment; Cuomo denies allegations. ALBANY, N.Y.-The New York state Assembly will hold public and private hearings this month as part of its impeachment investigation into Gov. Andrew Cuomo, attempting to conclude its work "with all due haste," key lawmakers said Monday.

title: 'Jeopardy!' Producer and Potential Host Mike Richards Responds to Backlash
summary: In letter to staff, executive producer, who emerged as front-runner in race to succeed Alex Trebek, addresses concerns about conflict of interest, allegations of gender bias. A leading contender to be full-time host of "Jeopardy!," one of the most closely watched hiring searches in show business, responded Monday to backlash against his candidacy for the job, including allegations of gender bias.

title: Democrats Outline $3.5 Trillion Plan, Senate to Vote on Infrastructure Bill
summary: Action on the budget proposal will come after the Senate wraps up bipartisan infrastructure bill. WASHINGTON-Senate Democrats released an outline of the $3.5 trillion antipoverty and climate plan on Monday, further detailing their ambitions for a major overhaul of the nation's education and healthcare systems that they hope to advance alongside a bipartisan infrastructure bill.

title: SEC Winds Down Bribery Inquiry Into Pactiv Evergreen
summary: Agency's decision comes after similar move by DOJ related to packaging company's disclosure of potential FCPA violations in IPO filing. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission intends to close an investigation into potential bribery violations that Pactiv Evergreen Inc. disclosed before an initial public offering last year, following a similar decision by the Justice Department.

title: Winging It (Tuesday Crossword, August 10)
Treasurys' Big Rally Gets Help From Skeptics of Low Rates
summary: Partial unwinding of crowded trade helps drive yields down to levels few thought they would see at time of strong growth, inflation. A little more than a month ago, Zhiwei Ren pared back his bet that strong growth and inflation would cause bond prices to fall and their yields to rise-even though he still believed in his economic forecast.

title: Chip Shortage Keeps CIOs and Other Tech Leaders Scrambling
summary: Across the economy, corporate tech leaders are dealing with dwindling supplies of the physical building blocks of IT. Companies inside and outside the tech sector are feeling the pinch of the global computer-chip shortage, which is stalling orders and raising prices on laptops, printers, smartphones, videoconferencing equipment and other work gear, corporate technology chiefs say.

title: Early Lordstown Motors Investor Workhorse Group Sold Most of Stake in Startup
summary: Workhorse sold 11.9 million shares in Lordstown since July 1. Electric delivery truck maker Workhorse Group Inc. said Monday it sold down much of its stake in Lordstown Motors Corp. this summer, reducing its equity position in the embattled Ohio-based startup.

title: Time's Up Chairwoman Roberta Kaplan Resigns Amid Cuomo Probe
summary: The Human Rights Campaign separately hired a law firm to investigate its president over allegations in New York attorney general's report. The chairwoman of the Time's Up advocacy group resigned Monday and the president of the Human Rights Campaign is under internal investigation as fallout from the report on New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo continues.

title: Oil Prices Slide on Worries That Delta Variant Will Crunch Demand
summary: Crude prices neared their lowest levels since May as investors worry that travel restrictions and delayed office reopenings will limit fuel consumption. A slide in oil accelerated on Monday as prices fell to around their lowest level in 2½ months, with traders worried that new restrictions to slow the spread of the Delta variant of the coronavirus could weaken the global economy and crunch fuel demand.

title: Biden Sanctions Belarus Olympic Committee, Companies
summary: President also signs an executive order enhancing his ability to punish the government of Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko. WASHINGTON-President Biden signed an executive order enhancing his ability to impose costs on the government of Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko along with new sanctions targeting individuals and business entities, including the country's Olympic committee.

title: Hertz Posts Higher Revenue, Plans to Relist Amid Travel Rebound
summary: Car-rental company's improved sales come as pandemic fears ease. Car-rental company Hertz Global Holdings Inc. said it plans to relist on a major stock exchange by the end of 2021 as its quarterly revenue surged amid a travel rebound.

title: Canada Reopens U.S. Border to Fully Vaccinated Americans
summary: Some U.S. citizens travel on Monday to reunite with romantic partners or visit property they own. CORNWALL, Ontario-Canada opened its border to fully vaccinated American tourists on Monday, raising hopes in border towns and tourist hot spots that businesses hit hard by the Covid-19 pandemic will get a boost from out-of-country visitors before the end of the summer.

title: Tyson Says Labor, Grain Costs Boost Meat Prices
summary: Meat giant says employee reaction to Covid-19 vaccine mandate 'mixed'; beef, chicken business propels profits. Tyson Foods Inc. projected higher meat costs ahead, as the meat company seeks to pass along elevated prices for animal feed, increased wages and ongoing pandemic expenses to restaurants and supermarkets.

title: Biden's Illegal, Wrongheaded Eviction Ban
summary: It is an unconstitutional 'taking' of the landlord's property.. I join the editorial board in befuddlement at "The Rental Evictions Fiasco" (Aug. 2). When the federal government requires a landlord to give away a rental unit to a tenant, it is an unconstitutional "taking" of the landlord's property. At a minimum, landlords should be able to apply directly for compensation from the $43 billion of undistributed rental relief funds appropriated by Congress. This really isn't that complicated.

title: A Full-Court Press for Vaccination
summary: An $100 fine would change minds.. In "It's Time to Start Requiring Covid Vaccines" (Politics & Ideas, July 28), William Galston offers an excellent summary and analysis of Jacobson v. Massachusetts (1905). His comment that the state has options to "compel" vaccination, however, is not entirely accurate. The Supreme Court did not rule that by state police power Jacobson could be compelled to be vaccinated, but only that on his refusal he could be fined the $5 amount in the state statute and be committed if he didn't pay. Five dollars then is equivalent to about $150 today. I would bet that many people looking at a $100 or $150 fine would change their mind about vaccination.

title: The Fed Indirectly Shrinks the Money Supply
summary: Actions reducing reserves tend in turn to induce banks to reduce lending.. In their Aug 6. letter in response to our op-ed "How the Fed Is Hedging Its Inflation Bet" (Aug. 2), John Greenwood and Steve Hanke argue that the Fed's sale of a trillion dollars of reverse repos does not in and of itself reduce the deposit liabilities of banks and money-market mutual funds, and that the money supply is unaffected. By that logic, none of the monetary tools of the Federal Reserve Bank would affect the money supply.

title: Athletes Protest in Uniform Against Racism in Uniform
summary: The leadership of the U.S. Olympic team should be applauded.. As retired Air Force colonels, Ken Faulhaber and I share our institution's values: "Integrity first, service before self, excellence in all we do." But we part company when he asserts that protests by those in Team USA uniforms are "inappropriate" (Letters, Aug. 5). He fails to appreciate that U.S. athletes are protesting in part against the acts of those in uniforms of their own-police uniforms-who violated their "rules of engagement." The leadership of the U.S. Olympic team should be applauded for allowing team members to protest in uniform the behavior of those who would discriminate against them while in uniform.

title: Coinbase Head of Capital Markets Leaves After Four Months
summary: Former SEC official was a high-profile hire by the cryptocurrency exchange this year. Brett Redfearn, a former federal regulator who joined Coinbase Global Inc. earlier this year, has left the cryptocurrency exchange after about four months on the job.

title: Available Jobs Outnumber Unemployed Americans Seeking Work
summary: Openings rose to a record 10.1 million in June; some economists see unfilled jobs leveling off this summer. Available jobs in the U.S. rose to another record high at the end of June, pushing openings above the number of unemployed Americans seeking work, a sign of an unusually tight labor market.

title: Government Failure Gave the World Covid
summary: And markets provided the remedy. Economists don't always appreciate how often that happens.. The dispute between Sen. Rand Paul and Anthony Fauci about the Wuhan Institute of Virology's role in the Covid-19 pandemic gets to the heart of economic policy. Economists are trained to believe that the purpose of government policy is to correct market failures: Capitalism has undesirable side effects, such as excessive pollution or inequality, that must be ameliorated by the state. The lessons of the Covid-19 pandemic, the most important recent event affecting the world economy, demonstrate the opposite.

title: Climate Change Has Consumed Journalistic Standards
summary: Reporters used to be hard-bitten skeptics. Now they aspire to be part of the authoritative expert class.. 'Is this the end of summer as we've known it?" a New York Times headline asked the other day, with characteristic hysteria. (It's an old truth in journalism circles: when a newspaper headline asks a question, the answer is almost always no: "Has This Man Found a Cure for Baldness? Are We All Going to Be Vegans? Is This the Start of a New Era for the Jets?")

title: How Cuomo Could Be Impeached: What to Know
summary: Several women have accused Cuomo of sexual harassment; Democratic governor denies the allegations. Investigators for state Attorney General Letitia James concluded in an early August report that Mr. Cuomo broke state and federal sexual-harassment laws by inappropriately touching or making comments to 11 women, including current and former aides and state workers. The report was commissioned last spring, following a series of allegations by several of the women, which also helped prompt an impeachment investigation by the New York state Assembly.

title: Judge Weighs Eviction Ban Ruling
summary: Federal judge who invalidated previous moratorium questions whether she can block the new one. WASHINGTON-A federal judge on Monday questioned the legality of the Biden administration's new eviction moratorium, but also expressed uncertainty about whether she has the authority to block it.

title: Oil Giant Aramco Sees Growth Where Others Eye Transition
summary: Decarbonization strategies and uncertainty about global demand have tempered most oil-and-gas investment, but the world's largest producer still plans to expand. Even as calls to cut carbon-dioxide emissions ring ever louder, Saudi Aramco is mobilizing to pump more oil. The strategy makes sense on its own terms, but isn't without risk.

title: When Will the Canada-U.S. Border Reopen? What We Know
summary: Canada began allowing entry to fully vaccinated U.S. tourists beginning Aug. 9; U.S. restrictions remain. For more than 16 months, the U.S. and Canada turned away tourists at entry points across the 5,500-mile land border in an effort to contain further spread of Covid-19. In light of progress in both countries on the Covid-19 vaccination front, business groups pushed Washington and Ottawa to reopen border crossings-to the fully vaccinated, at least at the start.

title: Judge Sides With Norwegian Cruise Line in Suit Over Vaccination Proof in Florida
summary: Norwegian is set to offer cruises from Florida to the Caribbean starting Aug. 15; company is requiring passengers to be fully vaccinated before boarding. A federal judge has for now sided with Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Ltd. in its bid to invalidate Florida's rule that bars businesses from requiring proof of Covid-19 vaccination from their customers.

title: DraftKings to Buy Golden Nugget Online Gaming for About $1.56 Billion in Stock
summary: Deal is expected to close in first quarter of 2022. DraftKings Inc. has agreed to buy Golden Nugget Online Gaming Inc. for about $1.56 billion in stock, a deal that would boost the sports-betting operator's online-casino-games offering, the companies said.

title: Sending Smiley Emojis? They Now Mean Different Things to Different People
summary: Resume Subscription. A smiley face isn't always just a smiley face. Behind the yellow, wide-eyed emoji's grin lurks an intergenerational minefield.

title: In Their Own Words With XPV Water Partners' David Henderson
summary: David Henderson, managing partner at XPV Water Partners, shares his thoughts on what lies ahead for the water-infrastructure sector. Real-assets investments have attracted growing interest among institutional investors in recent years, thanks partly to concerns over inflation risk, low yields in traditional bond markets and a mounting inventory of deteriorating infrastructure in need of repair and renewal. Investors have poured capital into funds focused on different subsectors of real assets, most notably infrastructure. We caught up with investors who touch the different corners of the real-assets world to get their perspectives on what lies ahead for their respective subsectors. Responses have been edited for clarity and style.

title: Jefferies Raises Junior Pay to Match Goldman Sachs
summary: The bank's first-year analysts in the U.S. will now make $110,000, up from $85,000. Jefferies Financial Group Inc. will match Goldman Sachs Group Inc. at the top of Wall Street's pay scale for younger bankers, according to people familiar with the matter, in a bid to go head-to-head with better-known rivals.

title: Even Kanye's Doing It. The Craze for OutfitGrid-Style Photos
summary: On @Outfitgrid, an Instagram account with over 777,000 followers, people compete to see whose carefully composed photo of their wardrobe will be declared that day's winner.. In December 2012, Dennis Todisco plopped a Supreme hoodie, a pair of red-and-black Jordans and a set of sweatpants on his floor and arranged it into a ghostly still life. He snapped a photo of this outfit and posted it to @Outfitgrid, an Instagram page he had just started. With that, a social media phenomenon was born. Over the past nine years, @Outfitgrid has exploded into one of the leading men's style pages on Instagram. It counts over 777,000 followers including musician/gorpcore-hero John Mayer, rapper Pusha T and former NBAer Nick Young. Those followers are 75% males, with the bulk of them aged 18 to 24 (and 25-to-34-year-olds making up the next largest group).

title: Citigroup Reaches First Deal of Jane Fraser's Refresh
summary: NAB, one of the four dominant banks in Australia, will pay Citigroup about $184 million for the book of mortgages, credit cards and deposits. Citigroup Inc. will sell its Australian consumer operations to National Australia Bank Ltd. , the first deal in Chief Executive Jane Fraser's attempt to remake the global bank's reach.

title: Election-Season Chaos No Longer Far-Fetched, but Preventable
summary: Slimmer federal elections law could give both Democrats and Republicans what they want. On Jan. 3 of this year-amid the furor over former President Donald Trump's claims of a "rigged" election, and three days before a mob of his supporters stormed the Capitol-Texas Rep. Chip Roy made a radical proposal that attracted little attention.

title: Cargill, Continental Grain to Acquire Sanderson Farms
summary: The approximately $4.5 billion deal values the poultry giant at $203 a share. Sanderson Farms Inc. agreed to sell itself for around $4.5 billion as the poultry giant rides a wave of demand for chicken products.

title: Senate Moves Closer to Passing Infrastructure Bill
summary: Lawmakers moved forward on procedural votes on a bipartisan basis. WASHINGTON-The roughly $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill cleared a final set of procedural hurdles in the Senate, putting the legislation on track to easily pass the chamber in the coming days.

title: As the Dixie Fire and Others Burn, the U.S. Struggles to Find Enough Firefighters
summary: Resume Subscription. Willy Sloop left his job as a wildland firefighter for the U.S. Forest Service about two years ago. This year he has gotten multiple emails asking if he wants to come back.

title: How Schools Are Rewriting the Rules on Class Time for Students-and Even Ditching Grade Levels
summary: Educators are testing competency-based education, a form of personalized learning that emphasizes mastery of skills over hours spent in a classroom. Author

title: The Olympics Are Deeply Flawed. But the Games Still Matter.
summary: The institution is marred by arrogance and excess. But the athletes keep delivering indelible moments.. A high jump gold medal, shared. A sequel to the wrestling match of the century. The most decorated U.S. track and field athlete ever. A seven-medal swimmer. Historic gold in women's volleyball. Double U.S. gold in golf. And a sudden dialogue about mental health that might outlast all of it.

title: After Tokyo, Beijing Olympics Promise Colder Weather but Hotter Rhetoric
summary: Nationalist fervor in China is poised to define the 2022 Winter Games; ticket sales uncertain with only six months to go. If the just-concluded Tokyo Olympics were memorable for the silence of empty competition venues, the upcoming Beijing Winter Olympics are shaping up to be dominated by high-decibel politics.

title: Pool Company's Stock Is on the Diving Board
summary: Pool Corp. is thriving amid a pool construction and renovation boom, but its overheated share price is in danger of taking a plunge. This column is part of the Heard on the Street stock-picking contest. You're invited to play along with us here.

summary: Energy companies were slipping as crude prices fell. S&P 500 futures are slightly lower, suggesting the broad index will hover near its record high-but a drop in oil prices and volatility in gold suggest nervousness about the outlook as Covid-19 cases surge. Here's what we're watching ahead of Monday's open.

title: Russia's New Jet Fighter Aims to Rival U.S. in Air-and on Geopolitical Map
summary: Checkmate could compete with the F-35 and contest U.S. strategic leverage if Russian manufacturers can get it off the ground. At Russia's premier expo for military aircraft in July, Russian President Vladimir Putin inspected a prototype jet that is designed to take on more than enemy fighters. The lightweight stealth plane also is meant to cause geopolitical headaches for the U.S.

title: What Marc Maron's Learned From Hosting Over 1,200 Episodes of His Podcast
summary: The actor and comedian also tells us how he's been smoking his own fish for breakfast.. In our series My Monday Morning, self-motivated people tell WSJ. how they start off the week.

summary: Victoria's Secret shares jumped on their debut as a stand-alone company but remain cheap. This column is part of the Heard on the Street stock-picking contest. You're invited to play along with us here.

title: American National Group to Be Sold to Brookfield Reinsurance Arm
summary: Deal values insurer at $190 a share or about $5 billion. The reinsurance arm of Brookfield Asset Management Inc. has agreed to buy American National Group Inc. for about $5 billion, the companies said.

title: Alibaba Fires Manager Accused of Sexual Assault in China's Latest Workplace Harassment Case
summary: Two other employees resign, according to CEO's memo, after woman's allegations were shared across Chinese social media. An Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. manager accused of sexual assault by an employee has been fired, and two other employees, including a senior executive, have resigned, according to a memo to company staff from Chief Executive Daniel Zhang.

title: R. Kelly's Trial on Federal Racketeering Charges Begins in Brooklyn
summary: The R&B singer is charged with leading a criminal enterprise, participating in kidnapping and the sexual exploitation of children. R&B singer R. Kelly is set to begin trial Monday on federal charges that he led a racketeering enterprise for two decades and used his managers, bodyguards, drivers and personal assistants to recruit women and underage girls for sex.

title: Vaccination Status Has Americans Picking Sides
summary: Some friends and families are divided over who have gotten vaccinated amid rising Covid-19 cases; 'it could just turn into a really nasty battle'. Weeks of rising Covid-19 cases have hardened divisions within families, communities and friend groups over which members have been vaccinated and which have chosen not to do so.

title: WeWork and Cushman & Wakefield Are Forming $150 Million Partnership
summary: Alliance aims to help landlords and tenants navigate returning to the office. Shared office space giant WeWork and Cushman & Wakefield PLC, one of the world's largest commercial real-estate firms, are negotiating to form a $150 million partnership to navigate the new world of remote working and flexible workplaces.

title: Jay Y. Lee, Samsung's De Facto Leader, Wins Parole From Prison
summary: Lee had been serving a 30-month prison sentence for bribing South Korea's ex-president. SEOUL- Samsung 's de facto leader, Lee Jae-yong, will be released from prison on parole later this week, though it remains unclear how-or if-he can return to work right away at South Korea's largest conglomerate.

title: Russian Quest for Mideast Sway Hit by New Syria Battle
summary: Moscow had supported the Syrian government and brokered a cease-fire with rebels in Daraa, but now the pact is breaking. Russia is finding that keeping the peace in Syria is harder than fighting its civil war, as a fierce assault by Syrian forces on a rebel-held town erodes Moscow's aim to cement itself as a major power broker in the Middle East.

title: A Guide to How Redistricting Will Shift Political Power
summary: Republicans have an upper hand in redrawing the lines of legislative districts. U.S. states will begin the once-a-decade process of redrawing the lines of their legislative districts when the government releases 2020 census figures later this month.

title: Can Europe Force China Onto a Low-Carbon Diet?
summary: The EU's newly proposed carbon border-adjustment mechanism is a key cudgel in the effort. Everyone knows dieting is hard and that it's easier if you have someone to do it with you. Europe has already committed to much lower carbon-dioxide emissions by 2030, and it is hoping the rest of the world will join in-particularly China, the world's largest emitter.

title: Heavy-Duty Truck Operators to Test Startup's Onboard Carbon-Capture System
summary: Remora has signed up several fleet operators in a pilot program to use its CO2-sucking tailpipe attachment. A handful of heavy-duty truck operators hope an early-stage startup can help lower the carbon emissions of their industry, one that has been particularly hard to clean up.

title: Rio Tinto Mismanagement Caused Copper Mine's Woes, Report Says
summary: Report rejects Rio Tinto's explanation that problems at Oyu Tolgoi mine were largely because of ground and geotechnical conditions. An expert group examining the cause of a $1.4 billion cost overrun at a giant copper mine run by Rio Tinto PLC in Mongolia said in a report that it was caused by mismanagement and not the unfavorable rock conditions blamed by the world's second-largest miner.

title: Finance Chiefs Work to Navigate Higher Costs, Transportation Woes
summary: E.l.f. Beauty is offering a smaller holiday assortment to save shipping-container space, while McCormick reduces packaging. Finance chiefs are making do with less as they work to reduce the impact of higher costs and supply disruptions on their businesses.

title: Delta Variant Clouds Back-to-School Shopping Plans
summary: Retailers predict record spending even as parents navigate concerns about rising Covid-19 cases and product shortages. Concerns over the Delta variant and supply-chain issues that have made it hard to find items like backpacks are upending back-to-school shopping plans for families, prompting some to curtail spending.

title: U.S. Steps Up Pressure on Businesses Over Forced Labor in China
summary: Beijing's alleged use of forced labor in Xinjiang emerges as a top item in the Biden administration's review of trade policy toward China. WASHINGTON-U.S. lawmakers and Biden administration officials are stepping up pressure on American businesses to stop imports from the Western Chinese region of Xinjiang as Beijing's alleged use of forced labor emerges as a top item on their bilateral trade agenda.

title: As Delta Variant Spreads, Florida Hospitals Race to Find Open Beds
summary: Resume Subscription. ORLANDO, Fla.-Nurse Darlene Andrews stood before a small crew responsible for stopping the latest pandemic surge from overrunning seven of AdventHealth's Orlando-area hospitals.

title: China's Producer Prices Jump Despite Efforts to Cool Commodities Costs
summary: Rise in factory-gate prices matches highest level in more than 12 years. BEIJING-China's factory-gate prices rose at an unexpectedly fast clip in July, matching the highest level in more than 12 years as crude oil and coal prices soared-though economists say the price pickup is unlikely to last.

summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: IPCC Report Says Some Climate Change Effects May Be Irreversible
summary: Resume Subscription. Rising seas, melting ice caps and other effects of a warming climate may be irreversible for centuries and are unequivocally driven by greenhouse-gas emissions from human activity, a scientific panel working under the auspices of the United Nations said Monday in a new report.

title: Olympic Flameout (Monday Crossword, August 9)
Melissa DeRosa, Top Aide to Gov. Andrew Cuomo, Resigns
summary: Resignation comes as New York governor faces impeachment inquiry over sexual harassment. ALBANY, N.Y.-Melissa DeRosa, the top aide to New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, said Sunday night she was resigning, as the Democratic governor faces a possible impeachment over sexual-harassment charges as well as a criminal investigation.
